major_name: Biochemistry (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Advanced Eukaryotic Genetics Winter 2025
I will generally send a brief response within 24h – but do not expect lengthy email responses.
The role of classical genetic analysis in the context of today's genomic era.
Methods used in model eukaryotic genetic organisms such as forward and reverse genetic screens, genetic mosaics, conditional mutants, and genetic mapping will be discussed.

Examples will illustrate how genes continue to be identified using classical-based approaches in a variety of biological processes, including cell cycle progression, cancer and metastasis, learning and memory, as well as pattern formation and embryonic development.
Alternatives to traditional mutagenesis-based screens and the links between classical and molecular genetics will also be discussed.

This course also strives to introduce students to some advanced concepts in classical genetics and to relate how classical genetics is relevant in today’s era of genome sequencing, genomics, proteomics, and genome editing.
1) Introduction & Review of 239 Material:

Prokaryotes vs. eukaryotes, Mendel’s Rules (two main laws), the dihybrib cross, the concept of genetic linkage, the stages of meiosis and the main events of meiosis, the chromosome theory of inheritance and its proof, recombination mapping (genetic distances), genetic maps vs. physical maps, polytene chromosomes.
2) Concepts for Genetic Analysis:

Model genetic organisms (general attributes and characteristics), balancer chromosomes and “balanced” genetic stocks, pericentric and paracentric inversions, methods of inducing genetic mutations, heterochromatin, RNAi, the genetic engineering and use of transposons as genetic tools
3) Details of Drosophila as a model genetic organism (MGO)
Tetrad Analysis in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Perkin’s Equation, Centromere Linkage in Ordered and Unordered Tetrads, Half Tetrad Analysis, crossover interference, sister chromatid exchange.
8) non-Mendelian Inheritance
Knowing how the complementation test can fool you, genetic modifiers, examples of genetic screens using MGOs, epistasis
11) CRISPR/Cas9 –– implications for model genetic systems and efficacy for gene therapy, and “genome editing”
Regain familiarity with the concepts introduced in BIOL 239, such as Mendel’s laws and classical based genetic analysis
Be in a good position to consider and evaluate possible graduate school projects in the areas of basic biomedical research, developmental or molecular biology
Learn to appreciate the laws of inheritance and exactly why organisms such as flies, worms, and yeasts have become major tools of basic research in genetics, cell biology, and developmental biology

course_name: CHEM310 - Transition Element Compounds and Inorganic Materials (0.50)
major_name: Biochemistry (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: The inorganic, organic, and solid state chemistry of the d-block elements.
The structure and physical properties of co-ordination compounds and transition metal containing solids.
The role of transition metal organometallics in catalysis.

The first (and major) part of the course will cover the chemistry and electronic structure of simple coordination compounds; the effects of ligand fields on magnetism, electronic spectra, substitution and redox behaviour will be examined.
In the second part, the properties of transition metal containing solids will be discussed along with the uses of these systems in, for example, lasers, and heterogeneous catalysts.
• Understand the important roles that transition metal inorganic chemistry plays in materials and biological processes;
• Describe and explain the bonding inherent to transition metal inorganic complexes;
• Discuss the impact and influence of the unpaired electrons in the d-block elements in the spectroscopic, optical and magnetic properties of the materials and proteins that contain them;
• Apply basic crystal field and molecular orbital concepts to explain the structures of coordination complexes.
Configuration of d-elements, d-orbitals and shapes of coordination complexes.
Crystal field effects in transition metal chemistry.
Module 2: Symmetry, group theory, and character tables for inorganic complexes.
Metal-ligand σ and π-bonding, and the origin of the spectro-electrochemical series.
Module 4: Optical and Magnetic properties of TM complexes.
Electronic and charge-transfer spectra of transition metal ions.
Magnetic behaviour of metal ions.
Descriptive chemistry of various geometries and the complexes that form them.
Reduction and oxidation chemistry of the transition metal elements
Substitutions; thermodynamic and kinetic stability; mechanisms of redox reactions in proteins.
Carbonyl complexes and metallocenes.

topics: Notice of Recording
Special Topics in Chemistry Winter 2025
A selection of current and advanced topics of interests in many areas of chemistry.
"Quantum Mechanics in Chemistry" is the title for this section of Chem400

In the Winter 2025 term the focus of the course will be electronic structure theory and a smaller segment on coupled electron-nuclear motion, developing theory beyond the Born Oppenheimer approximation.
The course will cover a description of the basic electronic structure problem introducing an atomic orbital basis set, Slater determinants and the Slater-Condon rules.
In another segment we will discuss vibronic coupling, introducing diabatic electronic states and simple model problems and introduce techniques to solve them using simple Python programs.
Have a good understanding of the electronic structure problem in Chemistry and how it connects to thermochemistry.
Have an in depth understanding of the Hartree-Fock method and the basic Hartree-Fock algorithm.
Be able to construct Hamiltonian matrix for small problems using Slater-Condon rules
Have introductory knowledge of Coupled Cluster methods for ground and excited states, and the concept of size-consistency.
Have introductory understanding of non-adiabatic nuclear dynamics going beyond the Born-Oppenheimer approximation.
Week 1,2: General introduction to quantum mechanics and the main uses in chemistry / thermochemistry.
Discussion of fundamental principles of Density Functional Theory.
Extension to multiple electronic surfaces.
Vibronic models beyond Born-Oppenheimer.

topics: STC 4018
STC 4018
However, we do run multiple labs at the same time which means we may not always be in the office.
Situation
Please email Dr. Gurska directly at jola.gurska@uwaterloo.ca
What does it mean to be a cell biologist?
One group of scientists might explore growing tissues in a laboratory to one day produce artificial skin or organs.

No matter what their question, cell biologists use a similar set of laboratory skills that allow them to peek inside the tiniest of biological units that make up the diversity of organisms we see around us.

Although fundamental techniques like microscopy have hugely advanced since the invention of the light microscope, every cell biologist needs to learn how to properly use a microscope to see cells reliably.
These can be very tricky to use properly but doing so could be the difference between a world-changing discovery and an experiment that no one can replicate.
These and other methods that are integral to working in the cell biology field will be introduced in this laboratory and it is my hope that you will leave confident in these fundamental techniques.
Maintain a well-organized and comprehensive lab book.
Identify elements of a well-structured laboratory report and write some elements of a lab report.
Assignment 3 Model Organisms and Experimental Design 3%

Holding a micropipette upside down with liquid in the micropipette tip,
Setting a micropipette precariously close to the edge of the bench so that it may fall on the floor,
Forcing the pipettes past their minimum and maximum calibrated ranges
Keeping a thorough lab book is a critical skill learned in a biology laboratory to document key observations and procedures.

Some reagents will already be set up to use at your bench, while others will be in dispensing bottles on the side bench or in the fume hoods, in which case the liquid must be dispensed directly from the bottles.
These can be purchased at the W Store Essentials in the STC.
Since many standard laboratory reagents are volatile, please consider not wearing contact lenses in the laboratory.
When not in use, stools should be tucked away under-bench and personal items stowed underneath in cupboards.
Finally, please remember that safety should be a collective concern.

Introduction to the biology of bacterial and archaeal organisms.
Topics include cell structure and function, methods of cultivation, genetics, phylogeny and taxonomy, and metabolic and genetic diversity.
The course is intended to provide basic knowledge of the world of microorganisms and consideration of how we study the activities of these small inhabitants of the planet.
The knowledge gained in this course will also prepare you to succeed in more advanced courses in microbiology, microbial ecology, and molecular biology.
Explain the impact of microbiology on the evolution of life and on human society.
Describe the diversity of bacteria, archaea, and microbial eukaryotes and differentiate between the three domains of microbial life based on key characteristics.
List nutritional categories of microbial metabolism and identify appropriate methods for cultivating microorganisms from these categories.
Explain how microorganisms regulate gene expression in order to compete for limited energy and nutrients.
List methods and mechanisms for exchange and manipulation of microbial DNA.
Describe how modern molecular methods have impacted microbiology.

course_name: BIOL439 - Environmental and Natural Products Biochemistry (0.50)
major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Environmental and Natural Products Biochemistry Fall 2024
okey.igboeli@uwaterloo.ca
This course deals with the functions, distribution, and environmental ramifications of natural compounds produced by plants and other biological systems.

Natural products are those compounds usually described as secondary metabolites, i.e., those apparently non-essential products whose physiological and ecological functions are either obscure or are of peripheral importance to the organism.

However, many of these non-essential products have profound competitive, economic, and pharmacological significance; and as research proceeds, their physiological roles within the parent organisms are becoming clearer.
As well, this course has a strong emphasis on how environmental chemical and physical processes impact on living organisms and their biochemistry.
Describe the importance of physical, biological, and environmental concepts related to plant secondary metabolites.
Integrate physical, biological, and environmental concepts related to different plant secondary metabolites.
Introduction: Products of primary and secondary metabolism.
Importance of secondary metabolites.
Plant-derived pharmaceutical compounds
Some of the papers are background on different subjects covered, others are examples of current research involving environmental and natural products biochemistry.

This course includes the independent development and practice of specific skills, such as discussion of new knowledge in the field of natural products and their competitive, economic, and pharmacological significance.

4.2 Construct MO energy level diagrams for diatomic and polyatomic species using manual and symmetry-defined approaches.

topics: RCH 306

Instructor: Bill Power
An introduction to the first, second, and third laws of thermodynamics and the application of these laws to ideal systems, mixtures, and chemical reactions.

Thermodynamic principles are used to study changes in state, including phase changes, and to establish the link between the equilibrium constant and the properties of the substances involved in a chemical reaction.
This course is a basic introduction to thermodynamics with emphasis on applications in chemistry.
The course provides the necessary background to study changes in state of many physical and chemical systems.
Define and apply the four laws of thermodynamics
Identify, describe and ultimately design a variety of physical and chemical systems through their internal changes and/or interactions with their surroundings
Quantify internal energy U, heat q, work w, enthalpy H, entropy S and Gibbs energy G in that same variety of physical and chemical systems
Predict spontaneous change in systems of varying complexity
Explain and quantify transformations involving both pure substances and mixtures using thermodynamic concepts

topics: Physical Biochemistry Winter 2025
B. Power
Instructor: Bill Power
The use of diffusion, ultracentrifugation, osmotic pressure, electrophoresis and X-ray diffraction to study the properties of biopolymers.
This course is meant to provide you with a basic introduction to physical chemistry as applied to the life sciences with emphasis on applications in biochemistry.

This course will cover the basics of thermodynamics and their applications to biological molecules and systems, their transport properties, chemical and enzyme kinetics, and physical techniques used to establish and investigate the structures of biological macromolecules.

I will aim to provide you with all the background necessary to cover the many topics in this course, from entropy and thermodynamic principles from the 18th century to modern applications such as AI which resulted in half of the the 2024 Nobel Prize in Chemistry going to Google's DeepMind leaders Demis Hassabis and John Jumper for their development of AlphaFold, a protein structure database (of 220 million structures!).

In return you should have some familiarity with the basics of biochemistry and biological structures and terminology, as well as some comfort working with derivatives, including partial derivatives, integrals and differential equations.
Understand the four laws of thermodynamics and their applications to biological systems
Understand the importance of Gibbs free energy and chemical potential in describing physical and chemistry transformations
Understand the basics of chemical kinetics and rate laws and mechanisms
Be able to characterize enzyme kinetics using the Michaelis-Menten description and describe competition and inhibition in such mechanisms
Know how to apply and interpret structural tools such as optical and NMR spectroscopy, X-ray diffraction and computational tools to biological macromolecules
There will be online and in-class assignments, on a rotating interval of about two weeks.
It will occur in a 2.5 hour time slot sometime between April 9 and April 25 (I have no control over this scheduling).
Weeks 1 to 3:   Thermodynamics, its Laws and its Applications
Week 10:            Biomolecular Structure; Optical Spectroscopy
Weeks 11 to 12: NMR Spectroscopy; X-ray Diffraction; AI Methods and AlphaFold

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,
know how to classify differential equations,
know how to solve various classes of differential equations using numerical methods and exact methods, and

Unit 4 - Mechanical and Electrical Vibrations (Week 6)
Unit 5 - Series Solutions of Second-Order Linear Equations (Weeks 7 - 8)
Unit 8 - Systems of Differential Equations (Weeks 11 - 12)

topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

course_name: AMATH382 - Computational Modelling of Cellular Systems (0.50)
major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Computational Modelling of Cellular Systems Winter 2024
B. Ingalls
An introduction to dynamic mathematical modeling of cellular processes.
The emphasis is on using computational tools to investigate differential equation-based models.
This course provides an introduction to dynamic mathematical modeling of cellular processes.
The emphasis will be on using computational tools to investigate models of cellular phenomena.
The course then addresses models in four biological domains: metabolic networks, signal transduction pathways, gene regulatory networks and electrophysiology.
Intended Audience: Third and fourth year students interested in dynamic modelling in molecular cell biology.
Software: We will be making heavy use of packages for numerical simulation of differential equations.
Appendix C of the course notes consists of tutorials on MATLAB and XPPAUT, which is a GUI-based package for dynamical systems analysis.
Design and simulate ordinary differential equation models of chemical reaction networks
Investigate differential equation models using phase plane analysis, sensitivity analysis, and bifurcation analysis
Develop and interpret differential equation models of biomolecular networks in the context of cellular metabolism, signal transduction, gene regulation, and electrophysiology
Design and simulate stochastic models of gene regulatory networks
Provide critical analysis of kinetic models of intracellular networks in the scientific literature and communicate their potential and limitations
Kinetic Modelling of Biochemical Networks
Module 3. Dynamics and Stability

This course will provide students with an understanding of the fundamental concepts of the vertebrate immune system.
Topics will focus on the components of the immune system, innate and adaptive immunity, immune cell development, communication, and recognition of non-self leading to an immune response.
How organisms regulate health versus disease is a central concept in the life sciences and has been the subject of intense study for over 100 years.

An introduction to dynamic mathematical modeling of cellular processes.
The emphasis is on using computational tools to investigate differential equation-based models.
This course provides an introduction to dynamic mathematical modeling of cellular processes.
The emphasis will be on using computational tools to investigate models of cellular phenomena.
The course then addresses models in four biological domains: metabolic networks, signal transduction pathways, gene regulatory networks and electrophysiology.
Intended Audience: Third and fourth year students interested in dynamic modelling in molecular cell biology.
Software: We will be making heavy use of packages for numerical simulation of differential equations.
Appendix C of the course notes consists of tutorials on MATLAB and XPPAUT, which is a GUI-based package for dynamical systems analysis.
Design and simulate ordinary differential equation models of chemical reaction networks
Investigate differential equation models using phase plane analysis, sensitivity analysis, and bifurcation analysis
Develop and interpret differential equation models of biomolecular networks in the context of cellular metabolism, signal transduction, gene regulation, and electrophysiology
Design and simulate stochastic models of gene regulatory networks
Provide critical analysis of kinetic models of intracellular networks in the scientific literature and communicate their potential and limitations

major_name: Biochemistry - Biotechnology Specialization (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Email: graham.murphy@uwaterloo.ca
FMO theory, organometallics, and transition metal-catalyzed C-C bond formation.
Chemistry 360 builds on the concepts and chemistry taught in CHEM 264 and CHEM 265.
If you want to do well in CHEM 360, you should re-familiarize yourself with some of the material in your introductory organic chemistry courses.
More specifically, CHEM 360 will familiarize students with some of the modern synthetic methods for the formation of carbon-carbon sigma bonds in organic compounds.

An array of anionic, cationic, pericyclic, and organometallic methods will be introduced as part of three general sections, and the factors governing the mechanistic, stereochemical and regiochemical course of these processes will be presented and discussed as appropriate.

Section 1 will cover enols and enolates, condensations and a-substitutions of carbonyl compounds (acid- and base-catalyzed), and conjugate addition to a,b-unsaturated carbonyl compounds (acid- and base-catalyzed).

Section 2  will cover pericyclic reactions (cycloadditions under thermal and photochemical conditions), with an emphasis on how an appreciation of frontier molecular orbitals allows for prediction of the reactivity of the systems (thermal and photochemical conditions), as well as relative reaction rates, regiochemistry and stereochemistry.
Section 3  will present transition-metal catalysis and organometallic reactions, with a particular emphasis on Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions.
1) To learn to use curve arrow formalism to “push” pairs of electrons in writing resonance forms and in sketching electron flow in chemical reactions.
To be able to use the understanding of reactions mechanisms to predict the outcome of these chemical reactions (mechanistic reasoning to interpret pattern of reactivity).

4) To be able to identify intermediates versus transition states in an energy diagram for all fundamental condensation reactions and be able to determine the difference between kinetically and thermodynamically controlled reactions, identify equilibrium and reaction rates, and relate to the energy of the transitions state, starting material, and final products.
7) To be able to identify neutral cyclic transitions states, involving bond-forming and bond-breaking events, in cycloaddition reactions, under thermal and photochemical conditions.

To be able to use frontier molecular orbitals (FMO’s) to predict the reactivity of cycloadditions under thermal and photochemical conditions, as well as relative reaction rates, regiochemistry and stereochemistry (Endo rule).

11) To be able to generate catalytic cycles for common cross-coupling reactions, namely Suzuki, Stille, Heck, Sonogashira, and Buchwald-Hartwig (Buchwald-Hartwig amination), as well as variations involving carbon monoxide.

cheryl.duxbury@uwaterloo.ca
cheryl.duxbury@uwaterloo.ca
cheryl.duxbury@uwaterloo.ca

ca
Food preservation, spoilage, poisoning and modern concepts in quality assurance programs are studied.
Microorganisms interact with the human food supply in a number of ways; some we consider beneficial, others detrimental.
In this course we'll look at factors that influence microbial growth in food.
If uncontrolled, such growth can lead to food spoilage, and, in some cases the safety of the food may be compromised.
Techniques to preserve foods, thereby extending their shelf-life and reducing potential health hazards, will be considered.
Identify factors that influence microbial growth in foods
Relate concepts in food microbiology to core concepts in biology (evolution, cell structure, metabolism)
Differentiate between microbes as spoilage organisms, pathogens, and useful food fermenters
Predict how specific changes would affect food microbiology parameters in a given scenario
Determine appropriate techniques for microbial analysis of food and for food preservation

topics: Advanced Eukaryotic Genetics Winter 2025
I will generally send a brief response within 24h – but do not expect lengthy email responses.
The role of classical genetic analysis in the context of today's genomic era.
Methods used in model eukaryotic genetic organisms such as forward and reverse genetic screens, genetic mosaics, conditional mutants, and genetic mapping will be discussed.

Examples will illustrate how genes continue to be identified using classical-based approaches in a variety of biological processes, including cell cycle progression, cancer and metastasis, learning and memory, as well as pattern formation and embryonic development.
Alternatives to traditional mutagenesis-based screens and the links between classical and molecular genetics will also be discussed.

This course also strives to introduce students to some advanced concepts in classical genetics and to relate how classical genetics is relevant in today’s era of genome sequencing, genomics, proteomics, and genome editing.
1) Introduction & Review of 239 Material:

Prokaryotes vs. eukaryotes, Mendel’s Rules (two main laws), the dihybrib cross, the concept of genetic linkage, the stages of meiosis and the main events of meiosis, the chromosome theory of inheritance and its proof, recombination mapping (genetic distances), genetic maps vs. physical maps, polytene chromosomes.
2) Concepts for Genetic Analysis:

Model genetic organisms (general attributes and characteristics), balancer chromosomes and “balanced” genetic stocks, pericentric and paracentric inversions, methods of inducing genetic mutations, heterochromatin, RNAi, the genetic engineering and use of transposons as genetic tools
3) Details of Drosophila as a model genetic organism (MGO)
Tetrad Analysis in Saccharomyces cerevisiae, Perkin’s Equation, Centromere Linkage in Ordered and Unordered Tetrads, Half Tetrad Analysis, crossover interference, sister chromatid exchange.
8) non-Mendelian Inheritance
Knowing how the complementation test can fool you, genetic modifiers, examples of genetic screens using MGOs, epistasis
11) CRISPR/Cas9 –– implications for model genetic systems and efficacy for gene therapy, and “genome editing”
Regain familiarity with the concepts introduced in BIOL 239, such as Mendel’s laws and classical based genetic analysis
Be in a good position to consider and evaluate possible graduate school projects in the areas of basic biomedical research, developmental or molecular biology
Learn to appreciate the laws of inheritance and exactly why organisms such as flies, worms, and yeasts have become major tools of basic research in genetics, cell biology, and developmental biology

In the Winter 2025 term the focus of the course will be electronic structure theory and a smaller segment on coupled electron-nuclear motion, developing theory beyond the Born Oppenheimer approximation.
The course will cover a description of the basic electronic structure problem introducing an atomic orbital basis set, Slater determinants and the Slater-Condon rules.
In another segment we will discuss vibronic coupling, introducing diabatic electronic states and simple model problems and introduce techniques to solve them using simple Python programs.

Situation
Please email Dr. Gurska directly at jola.gurska@uwaterloo.ca
What does it mean to be a cell biologist?
One group of scientists might explore growing tissues in a laboratory to one day produce artificial skin or organs.

No matter what their question, cell biologists use a similar set of laboratory skills that allow them to peek inside the tiniest of biological units that make up the diversity of organisms we see around us.

Although fundamental techniques like microscopy have hugely advanced since the invention of the light microscope, every cell biologist needs to learn how to properly use a microscope to see cells reliably.
These can be very tricky to use properly but doing so could be the difference between a world-changing discovery and an experiment that no one can replicate.
These and other methods that are integral to working in the cell biology field will be introduced in this laboratory and it is my hope that you will leave confident in these fundamental techniques.
Maintain a well-organized and comprehensive lab book.
Identify elements of a well-structured laboratory report and write some elements of a lab report.

Keeping a thorough lab book is a critical skill learned in a biology laboratory to document key observations and procedures.

When not in use, stools should be tucked away under-bench and personal items stowed underneath in cupboards.
Finally, please remember that safety should be a collective concern.

The stoichiometry of compounds and chemical reactions.

Electronic structure of atoms and molecules; correlation with the chemical reactivity of common elements, inorganic and organic compounds.
The second part of this course is concerned with explaining periodicity and trends in chemical reactivity in terms of the electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

Topics covered in this part of the course include the quantum theory of the hydrogen atom; electron configurations in multi-electron atoms; ionic and covalent bonding; Lewis structures, valence shell electron repulsion theory and molecular geometry; quantum mechanical bonding theories, including valence bond theory and molecular orbital theory.
Additional topics may include an introduction to electron-transfer reactions, including the assignment of oxidation states and the balancing of oxidation-reduction reactions.

course_name: MATH228 - Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry (0.50)
major_name: Biological and Medical Physics (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Differential Equations for Physics and Chemistry Winter 2025
First-order equations, second-order linear equations with constant coefficients, series solutions and special functions, the Laplace transform method.
Applications in physics and chemistry are emphasized.
Differential equations capture how some variable of interest, such as the position of a planet, changes as a function of some independent variable, such as time.
Differential equations are very widely used in the sciences because of the broad range of real-world phenomena they can describe in a mathematical framework.

In this course, students will be introduced to the universe of differential equations, including first-order equations, second-order linear equations, series solutions, the Laplace transform method, and both exact and numerical methods for solving differential equations.
Applications in physics and chemistry will be emphasized.
understand how differential equations can be used to model physical systems,

Extended Course Description: This course is an introduction to physics in medicine and is intended to introduce students to various techniques and concepts in medical physics, including ionizing radiation, used in medicine particularly in oncology, for diagnosis and treatments of diseases.

The course has been designed to follow the basic curriculum of a Medical Physics training program where students will gain insight to the importance of radiological physics in medicine and issues associated.
The course is aimed at students with a career interest in medical physics and who may pursue graduate studies in medical physics.
Physical concepts covered include: Nuclear structure and nuclear decays, radioactivity and nuclear reactions.

major_name: Biological and Medical Physics (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Email: brenda.lee@uwaterloo.ca
Email: s2pattar@uwaterloo.ca

Introduction to imaging concepts in biophysics with emphasis on the interrelationship between the physics principles of an imaging modality and the associated image reconstruction; methods for imaging at macroscopic to microscopic scales; computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasound, PET, optical imaging, optical and fluorescence microscopy, scanning probe microscopy (AFM, STM), optical tweezers, electron microscopy.

Explain the fundamental physical principles underlying key medical imaging modalities, including radiography, computed tomography, nuclear medicine, ultrasound, magnetic resonance, and optical imaging.
Interpret mathematical representations of imaging processes, such as Fourier transforms and convolution, and relate them to practical imaging applications
Compare the capabilities, limitations, and applications of different medical imaging techniques in clinical and research contexts
Conduct a comprehensive literature review on a specific imaging topic, synthesizing current research to identify trends and gaps
Prepare and submit a structured and concise abstract for a mock scientific conference to meet professional standards
Design and present a visually engaging and scientifically accurate conference poster summarizing research findings from an existing paper
Apply critical thinking to interpret and discuss the biological and clinical implications of imaging technologies
Not all topics may be covered in their entirety, but the core topics from the course calendar description will.

2 Jan 13-17 Topic 2: Signals and Systems
Topic 15: Optical Imaging Techniques in Biophysics
12 Mar 24-28 Topic 16: Scanning Probe Microscopy & Advanced Methods in Biophysics Project Milestone #5: Conference Posters (PPT/PDF)
Apr 9: Final examination period begins
May 20: Standing decisions and official grades available in Quest
Level of Collaboration Allowed: None - Screening for Plagiarism Active
Introduction: a short review of the specified medical condition

Methods: a discussion of how at least three medical imaging and/or biophysical technologies reviewed in this course can apply to the specific medical condition, and what diagnostic information can be obtained through the use of different imaging technologies
Results: a summary of how some of the methods chosen have been used to study the medical condition; at least 2-3 studies must be reviewed here
Conclusion: a summary of which methods are best suited to provide the most diagnostically relevant and detailed information about the medical condition

major_name: Biological and Medical Physics (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Notice of Recording
Introduction to Biophysics Winter 2025
Email: brenda.lee@uwaterloo.ca
Email: ibukhteeva@uwaterloo.ca
Email: jglasier@uwaterloo.ca
Introduction to a physical understanding of biological systems at macro and molecular scales.

The course is intended for second-year science and engineering students and will cover a broad spectrum of topics in biophysics, as well as an introduction to neurobiology, nanotechnology, and biotechnology.
Explain fundamental physical principles as they relate to biological systems at the macro and molecular scales
Apply mathematical and physical models to describe and predict biological phenomena, including respiration, membrane transport, and energy transformation
Demonstrate a systemic approach to problem-solving in applying physical concepts to solve questions related to biological systems
Explore the structural and functional properties of biomolecules (proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, carbohydrates) and their role in cellular and molecular systems
Evaluate the role of physical laws in physiological processes, such as neuronal signal propagation and blood flow dynamics
Demonstrate knowledge of a wide range of biophysical and experimental methods (e.g. microscopy, spectroscopy, light scattering techniques) and their applications in research and medicine
Critically assess biophysical methods used in research and medical applications and highlight their benefits, limitations, potential
Develop scientific communication skills through the creation of written reports and problem-solving assignments related to biophysical concepts
Not all topics may be covered in their entirety, but the core topics from the course calendar description will.
1 Jan 6-10 Topic 1: Introduction to Biophysics
Topic 7: Introduction to Cellular & Molecular Biophysics
Topic 9: Biophysics of Nucleic Acid and DNA
Topic 14: Introduction to Bionanotechnology
Topic 16: Advanced Methods in Biophysics
Topic 17: Methods in Medical Physics

major_name: Biological and Medical Physics (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: Songmin Xu s83xu@uwaterloo.ca
Mastering Physics technical support: https://support.pearson.com/getsupport/s/
This is a fast-paced survey course (covering about one textbook chapter per week) introducing a wide range of topics in modern physics.

The intention is four-fold: (1) to make first-year physics more interesting; (2) to provide important, intuitive understanding of key modern physics concepts before your more mathematically rigorous courses in second year; (3) to help you decide which areas of physics you may wish to explore in more depth in upper-year electives; and (4) to have at least a brief introduction to important branches of physics you may not explore further in your degree.
Apply Newton's second law and Newton's law of universal gravitation to solve basic problems in gravitational physics.
Understand, distinguish between and correctly use the concepts of weight, weightlessness, and apparent weight.
Solve simple problems in orbital motion and apply Kepler's three laws.

Properly understand Einstein's two postulates and logically derive from them, and apply, the concepts of time dilation, length contraction, Doppler shift, velocity composition, relativity of simultaneity, and understand why special relativity works for both wave-in-ether and particle-in-vacuum models of light..
Articulate the basic, intuitive ideas of how Einstein's geometrical model of gravity works (equivalence principle and curved spacetime).
Appreciate that classical physics cannot explain the single or double slit experiments.
Understand and predict basic properties of the quantum hydrogen atom based on only the de Broglie relation and classical properties of electron orbits.
Understand the basic idea of a complex number, and in particular, a complex exponential wave, and use it to "derive" the Schrodinger equation.
Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate ionic bonds, covalent bonds, van der Waals bonds, and basic molecular spectra.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate the basic features of atomic nuclei, including nuclear binding energy, nuclear models, nuclear stability and radioactivity, nuclear reactions, nuclear fission, and nuclear fusion.

Use classical and quantum physics to understand/calculate some basic aspects of collider physics, including the concept of available energy, and an introduction to the Standard Model of particle physics.
Feb 24 Wave Functions Wave Functions
Mar 17 Nuclear Nuclear

topics: Email: alupascu@uwaterloo.ca
Email
Applications of nanotechnology in biology and medicine.
This course addresses the new physical phenomena arising when the dimensions of physical systems are reduced to micrometers or nanometers.
These systems are called mesoscopic, a word meant to indicate behavior that is distinct from that of both macroscopic and microscopic systems.
These principles will be applied to a discussion of the field effect transistor, a widely spread device.

The following topics in mesoscopic transport will be considered: the Landauer formula of quantized transport, the Landauer-Büttiker formalism for multiterminal conductors, the quantum Hall effect, phase coherent transport, Coulomb blockade, quantum dots, coherent transport in superconducting systems, carbon-based devices (graphene and carbon nanotubes), resonant tunneling.
A few applications of nanophysics based tools in biology and medicine will be discussed and a brief overview of ethical and regulatory aspects of nanoscience will be given as well.
The students will learn the principles that govern electronic transport at the nanoscale.

The field of mescoscopic electronic transport is a rich playground where concepts learned in courses including thermodynamics, electricity and magnetism, quantum mechanics, and solid-state physics can be applied and further understood.
The discussion of applications in biology and medicine is meant to serve as an illustration of the potential of nanosystems in these areas.
Introduction to nanophysics
Review of solid-state physics
The field effect transistor – the building block of classical electronics
Mesoscopic transport: transport modes, Landauer formula, Landauer - Büttiker formalism
The quantum Hall effect
Graphene and carbon nanotubes
Fabrication methods in nanoscience
Applications of nanoscience in biology and medicine
Nanoscience and society
A list of the topics and relevant material with a timeline for study will be kept on LEARN.

The physiology of major organ systems of the human body.

The combination of BIOL273 and BIOL373 covers all of the major topics of human physiology.

Describe how these five organ systems are organized in the human body.

Corresponding Silverthorn textbook chapters in parentheses for each unit.
This unit serves as an introduction to the study of the function of the five organ systems examined in this course (nervous, muscular, cardiovascular, respiratory, and immune).
Unit 1 will introduce how the organ systems work together to maintain homeostasis within the body.
The organization of the nervous system will be explored in this unit.
The types of cells found in the central and peripheral nervous system serve as a starting point to discuss their function within the nervous system.
Initially gross structure of skeletal muscle including the structure of a muscle fibre and myofibrils will be examined.
An exploration into the muscle contraction mechanism via excitation-contraction coupling will be examined to explain how muscles work.
This unit will start with an introduction into the heart and components of the cardiovascular system, which will be followed by cardiac muscle contraction mechanism.
In this unit we will examine the structure and function of the respiratory system, incorporating gas laws and ventilation.
Pulmonary function through lung compliance and elastance as well as the control of ventilation will be examined.
This unit will start with the general function of immune system and introduction to the types of pathogens that infect the body.
The anatomy of the immune system will be discussed returning to the role of haematopoiesis.
At the end of each unit there is a list of important terms and concepts to review.
Students are encouraged to read the material in assigned chapters for each unit for the assignments and term tests.

What does it mean to be a cell biologist?
One group of scientists might explore growing tissues in a laboratory to one day produce artificial skin or organs.

No matter what their question, cell biologists use a similar set of laboratory skills that allow them to peek inside the tiniest of biological units that make up the diversity of organisms we see around us.

Although fundamental techniques like microscopy have hugely advanced since the invention of the light microscope, every cell biologist needs to learn how to properly use a microscope to see cells reliably.
These can be very tricky to use properly but doing so could be the difference between a world-changing discovery and an experiment that no one can replicate.
These and other methods that are integral to working in the cell biology field will be introduced in this laboratory and it is my hope that you will leave confident in these fundamental techniques.

The physiology of major organ systems of the human body.
Topics include neurophysiology and peripheral nervous system, muscle, the cardiovascular system, the components of blood, respiratory system, and immune system.
The combination of BIOL273 and BIOL373 covers all of the major topics of human physiology.
Identify the components/structures of the following organ systems: nervous, muscular, cardiovascular, respiratory, and immune.
Describe how these five organ systems are organized in the human body.
Explain the function of each of these five organ systems.
Demonstrate the integration of these five organ systems in maintaining homeostasis.

Section 001 - 11:20AM

Official Grades and Course Access
Corresponding Silverthorn textbook chapters in parentheses for each unit.
This unit serves as an introduction to the study of the function of the five organ systems examined in this course (nervous, muscular, cardiovascular, respiratory, and immune).
Unit 1 will introduce how the organ systems work together to maintain homeostasis within the body.
The organization of the nervous system will be explored in this unit.
The types of cells found in the central and peripheral nervous system serve as a starting point to discuss their function within the nervous system.
Initially gross structure of skeletal muscle including the structure of a muscle fibre and myofibrils will be examined.
An exploration into the muscle contraction mechanism via excitation-contraction coupling will be examined to explain how muscles work.
This unit will start with an introduction into the heart and components of the cardiovascular system, which will be followed by cardiac muscle contraction mechanism.
In this unit we will examine the structure and function of the respiratory system, incorporating gas laws and ventilation.
Pulmonary function through lung compliance and elastance as well as the control of ventilation will be examined.
This unit will start with the general function of immune system and introduction to the types of pathogens that infect the body.
The anatomy of the immune system will be discussed returning to the role of haematopoiesis.

major_name: Biology (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: General Chemistry 1 Winter 2025
RCH 101
The stoichiometry of compounds and chemical reactions.
Energy changes in chemical systems.
Electronic structure of atoms and molecules; correlation with the chemical reactivity of common elements, inorganic and organic compounds.
The second part of this course is concerned with explaining periodicity and trends in chemical reactivity in terms of the electronic structure of atoms and molecules.

Topics covered in this part of the course include the quantum theory of the hydrogen atom; electron configurations in multi-electron atoms; ionic and covalent bonding; Lewis structures, valence shell electron repulsion theory and molecular geometry; quantum mechanical bonding theories, including valence bond theory and molecular orbital theory.
Additional topics may include an introduction to electron-transfer reactions, including the assignment of oxidation states and the balancing of oxidation-reduction reactions.
assess the greenness of a chemical reaction using Atom Economy and E-Factor metrics.
describe the electronic structure of atoms in terms of quantum theory using atomic orbitals and quantum numbers.
justify the organization of the periodic table and predict trends in the properties of the elements.
describe bonding in molecules in terms of atomic orbitals and molecular orbitals, and explain molecular shape and stability in terms of electron count.
describe the interactions of molecules in solids, liquids, and gases to compare physical and reactive properties.

major_name: Biology (Bachelor of Science - Honours)
topics: An introduction to physics for students intending to concentrate their further studies in biology, dentistry, medicine and paramedicine; includes particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.
The main physics principles and laws covered in PHYS 111 include: “Particle kinematics and dynamics, energy and momentum conservation, and rotational mechanics.”

PHYS 111 focuses on basic physics principles and laws, on conceptual understanding and problem-solving skills, and an appreciation for the power of physics in explaining how nature works, in the contexts of both the physical and life sciences.

Physics Principles and Laws: By the end of the course, students will be able to construct scientifically sound explanations of a variety of basic physical phenomena by applying basic physics principles/laws.
define linear momentum, and calculate and compare momenta of various real-life objects;
define and calculate impulse, and establish the conditions for conservation of linear momentum; and
apply the laws of conservation of momentum and energy to collisions.
Problem-Solving Skills and Strategies: By the end of the course, students will be able to creatively apply a variety of structured problem-solving strategies:
interpret, visualize and convert the problem into a physical model (e.g., draw a free body diagram);
evaluate the result — does it make sense?
These problem-solving skills are useful in the students’ own disciplines and beyond.

Topics related to biomedical design will be covered: multidisciplinary system design, design process, problem definition, life-cycle design, design specification, function analysis, design evaluation and decision-making, introduction to mechanical design, prototyping, experimentation, safety and responsibility in engineering design, design for society and environment, and design documentation.
Knowledge Base - Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
Problem Analysis - An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation - An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

Design - An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, and economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
Communication Skills - An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the abilityto comprehend and write effectivereports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism - An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
Impact of Engineering - An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Lifelong Learning - An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

Introduction to the basic theory and principles of mechanics of static systems.
Applications of mechanical principles to musculoskeletal systems will be presented.
Basic concepts of mechanics, vectors.
Analysis of trusses and frames.
Distributed forces, centroids, and moments of inertia.
Engineering mechanics involves the combination of physics and mathematics to develop models of physical world and solve problems in the physical world.
In this course, you will acquire knowledge of the theory and principles of engineering mechanics of static systems and become proficient in problem solving in this area.

You will acquire skills in analysing a problem, developing a plan to solve the problem including creating a mechanics-based model of the system, and proceeding to solve the problem with full understanding of the fundamentals and approach, not by memorization.
Examples of the application of statics to mechanics of materials and musculoskeletal biomechanics will be discussed.
A) Conduct vector mathematics operations (addition, subtraction, vector products)
B) Calculate moments, centres of mass, and forces for particular structures.
C) Describe position, forces, and moments in terms of vector in appropriate reference frames in two and three dimensions.
E) Simplify systems of forces and moments to equivalent systems.
F) Draw complete free-body diagrams and write appropriate equilibrium equations from the free-body diagram, including the support reactions on a structure.
H) Determine the internal forces in a structure.
a) Demonstrate understanding of concepts in mathematics A, B, C  All
b) Demonstrate understanding of concepts in natural science B, C, D, E, F, G, H  All
c) Demonstrate understanding of engineering fundamentals F, G, H, I  All
a) Generate appropriate documentation to communicate within the profession and to society at large F, I, J  All

Design of human-machine environments, designing for patient safety and reduce human error in decision-making, analytical methods of determining user needs, information processing and human sensory processes and consideration of these elements in the design of systems with humans, and consideration of human physical capabilities in ergonomic design.

Knowledge Base - Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the program.
Problem Analysis - An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation - An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

Design - An ability to design solutions for complex, open-ended engineering problems and to design systems, components or processes that meet specified needs with appropriate attention to health and safety risks, applicable standards, and economic, environmental, cultural and societal considerations.
Communication Skills - An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism - An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
Impact of Engineering - An ability to analyze social and environmental aspects of engineering activities.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Lifelong Learning - An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

View requirements for BME 281
BME 281 is a required course for all 2A Biomedical Engineering students.
This course serves as a fundamental course to understand the mechanical behavior of materials.
The objective of this course is to introduce laws governing the elastic behavior of deformable solids and apply these laws to biological materials.
What are the flexural properties of the stick?
Given a structure and a loading, you will be able to identify critical section/s (sections that carry most load) of the structure and make sure they are strong enough to withstand the loading.
One of the main trends in today’s design optimization is the reduction of the weight.
We will start by introducing the concepts of stress and strains as measures of loading and deformation of bodies.
The Hooke’s law of linear elasticity that sets a relationship between stresses induced in a member and corresponding deformation is introduced.
Compound loading of structures and methods for identifying critical sections are then demonstrated.

Calculation of maximum normal and shear stresses in a member through Mohr’s circle is introduced and combined with the failure criteria to examine the structural integrity of the components under different load cases.
The course will end with introduction to mechanical behavior of biological materials.

topics: Biomedical Engineering Ethics Winter 2025
I can also be reached by Teams for all virtual meetings.

This course explores ethical issues in biomedical engineering practice, including professional ethics, medical ethics, the ethics of human and animal subject use in biomedical research, and the impact of biomedical engineering solutions on society and the environment.

This course aims to guide students in understanding the complex relationships between design, biomedical technologies and society and to appreciate how such an understanding can improve design outcomes from the user, community, national, and global perspectives.

Identify and evaluate considerations that influence ethical decisions regarding design, modification, and use of biomedical technologies, and the ethical concepts and arguments relevant to these practices (6 a, b, c; 7 a, b; 10 a, b, c);
Create rational solutions to ethical situations of concern related to biomedical engineering (6, 7);
Demonstrate an understanding of the social responsibilities of biomedical engineers (8 a, b);
Describe the importance of social factors affecting development, uptake, and impact of biomedical technologies on society in both developed and developing countries (7, 8).
This course will focus on and primarily measure your aptitude in the following graduate attributes:
Demonstrate knowledge of effective team attributes and processes
Communication skills  An ability to communicate complex engineering concepts within the profession and with society at large.

Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Can present information, arguments and analyses accurately and reliably within the profession and to society at large using appropriate documentation and vocabulary
Professionalism  An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.
Articulate the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society with reference to the protection of the public and its interest.
Describe the importance of codes, standards, best practices, laws, and biomedical regulations within engineering.
Identify ethical and unethical behaviour in professional situations (including the use of biomedical technologies).
in engineering projects.
Identify equitable and inequitable situations or behaviours

Critical Analysis of a Biomedical Ethical Situation of Concern

The topic of the paper will be the description, analysis, and critique of a biomedical or other ethical situation of concern you have experienced; it could be a situation encountered during a co-op work term, by a close family member, or by a friend.

The exam will consist of a mix of multiple-choice questions similar to the midterm but weighted toward material covered after the reading week, and an 'ethical situation of concern' (ESOC), similar to those in the tutorials.

I completed my PhD in the philosophy of physics (specializing in foundations of quantum mechanics) at Western University, and completed a post-doc in the School of Environment and Resource Studies at UW.

My research focusses on the nature of scientific knowledge, its bearing on climate change governance and other social policies, and problems of social coordination and game theory in what ecologists call the 'Anthropocene'.

major_name: Biomedical Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Control Systems Fall 2024
Ramisha Anjum, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, E7-5308, r3anjum@uwaterloo.ca
Alexander Kitaev, Department of Electrical and Computer Engineering, EIT 3131, alexander.kitaev@uwaterloo.ca
Classical and state space representations of control systems.
Routh-Hurwitz and root-locus methods.
Pole placement, PID, phase-lead and phase-lag controllers.
Application to anatomical system models, including musculoskeletal and cardiovascular systems, and to physiological feedback systems.

The principles of automatic control are employed throughout many branches of engineering: in analog electronics, feedback makes amplifier gains less sensitive to variations in transistor parameters, and improves input and output impedances and frequency response; in chemical and mechanical engineering, automatic controllers regulate temperatures, pressures and flow rates against a range of disturbances; robots robustly perform high-speed, precision manufacturing operations by means of numerous feedback controllers acting in concert to adjust respective joint angles; autopilots control the altitudes of aircraft and damp out undesirable oscillations that are difficult or impossible for human pilots to manage; automobiles incorporate computer-based ignition, emission control, braking and cruise control systems; satellite communications are enabled by the precise orientation of antennas and satellites.
This course is an introduction to these valuable engineering principles.
The same feedback principles are observed in natural systems, including biological organisms.
An understanding of control-engineering principles is fundamental to an appreciation of many physiological phenomena.

The mathematical framework of the course is the relatively simple one of linear time invariant systems (as seen in BME 252) – in both the time and frequency domains; the main system model is the transfer-function representation of single-input, single-output systems.
Classical control has a practical flavour, admitting and promoting the use of considerable engineering intuition.
a) explain Laplace transforms and transfer functions, key components of feedback control systems, and main response characteristics of control systems; (1c, d)
b) formulate, model, and solve control systems design and analysis problems; (2, 4)
c) apply block diagram reduction methods to find the overall transfer function of a given feedback control system; (2)
d) apply the Routh-Hurwitz criterion to investigate the stability of an LTI system for different values of system parameters; (2)
e) apply the Root-Locus method to tune the gains of lead/lag or PID controllers for a given set of time-domain response characteristics; (2)
f) construct and interpret the Bode diagram (magnitude and phase) for a given LTI control system; (1c, d)
g) apply the Nyquist criterion to investigate the stability of a given LTI control system for different values of the control system parameters; (2) and
h) employ computer programs and engineering tools properly for control systems design and analysis.
Week Chapter Pertinent sections of reference Learning outcome (LO) & Engineering tools
1 Introduction to feedback control Ch 1 LO a; Eng Tools: concepts of tracking, regulation, stability
3 Review of transfer function manipulation 2.5-2.7 LO c; Eng Tools: block-diagram reduction
4 Control system configurations 4.1-4.6 LO a, b; Eng Tools: feedforward and feedback architecture
7,8 Design using the root locus 7.1-7.6, 10.5, 10.7 LO e, h; Eng Tools: root-locus sketching and application to control

This course examines key economic issues in health care and biomedical industries.
Topics include the market for medical care, health insurance, various models of healthcare delivery and competition and the role of government in policy, financing and delivery of health care.
This course will train students to use economic analysis to model and understand the complex interactions between health care delivery, insurance markets, health innovators, governments, and firms.

A knowledge base for engineering:   Demonstrated competence in university level mathematics, natural sciences, engineering fundamentals, and specialized engineering knowledge appropriate to the biomedical engineering program.
2. Problem analysis:  An ability to use appropriate knowledge and skills to identify, formulate, analyze, and solve complex engineering problems in order to reach substantiated conclusions.

Investigation:  An ability to conduct investigations of complex problems by methods that include appropriate experiments, analysis and interpretation of data, and synthesis of information in order to reach valid conclusions.

4. Such ability includes reading, writing, speaking and listening, and the ability to comprehend and write effective reports and design documentation, and to give and effectively respond to clear instructions.
Professionalism:   An understanding of the roles and responsibilities of the professional engineer in society, especially the primary role of protection of the public and the public interest.

Such ability includes an understanding of the interactions that engineering has with the economic, social, health, safety, legal, and cultural aspects of society, the uncertainties in the prediction of such interactions; and the concepts of sustainable design and development and environmental stewardship.

Life-long learning:  An ability to identify and to address their own educational needs in a changing world in ways sufficient to maintain their competence and to allow them to contribute to the advancement of knowledge.

E. Boghaert
E. Boghaert

Fundamental concepts in systems involving fluid flow.
Basic treatment of statics, kinematics, and dynamics of fluids.
Mass transfer, conservation of mass, momentum and energy for a control volume.

Apply the integral form of the conservation of mass, Newton’s 2nd law of motion and the conservation of energy equation to a control volume to determine quantities of interest in fluid dynamics (average velocity, pressure drop, etc.).
Develop and solve one-dimensional steady-state mass transfer models.

major_name: Biomedical Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Optimization and Numerical Methods Fall 2024
- Abbas Seifi, Professor   Email: aseifi@uwaterloo.ca
Seyed Mohammad Amin Mirjalili Email:   smamirja@uwaterloo.ca

Interpolation and curve fitting, root-finding methods, local and global optimization methods, constrained optimization, multiobjective and multidisciplinary design optimization for biomedical applications.
This course introduces the applications of optimization modeling and numerical methods to biomedical engineering and engineering design.
It provides an overview of the formulation and classification of optimization problems arising in biomedical engineering and types of suitable optimization methods.

Graphical solution methods for two-variable problems and optimization techniques for single-variable problems like region elimination approaches, interpolation algorithms, and direct root methods are discussed.
Linear Programming problem formulations and simplex and interior methods for solving these problems are discussed.
Learn about different types of optimization problems in biomedical engineering and engineering design (GA: 1,4)

2. Study types of optimizations methods and where they are applied, convexity, optimality criteria for unconstrained multivariable problems, and optimality conditions for constrained multivariable problems and proper software tools (GA: 1,2,5)

Apply graphical solution method to solve two-variable optimization problems, and region elimination methods, interpolation methods, and direct root-finding methods to solve single-variable problems (GA: 1,2,5)
Apply simplex and interior-point methods for solving Linear Programming problems (GA: 1,2,5)
7. Apply constrained multivariable methods as well as multi-objective techniques to solve biomedical engineering and design optimization problems using Pareto optimality concept (GA: 3,4,5)

topics: Biomedical Engineering Design Workshop 2 Fall 2024
The first half of a two-term engineering design project continuing the biomedical design workshop sequence.
A prototype and interim progress report are presented at the end of the first term.
• 0.25-2 hours for in-person course activities and meetings as scheduled.

All accredited engineering programs in Canada culminate in a significant open-ended engineering design experience, which should involve teamwork and project management, and be conducted under the professional responsibility of faculty licensed to teach and/or practice engineering in Canada.

The main goal of BME461 and BME462 is to have 4th year BME students demonstrate appropriate competencies by applying engineering design knowledge and skills gained throughout their BME undergraduate program to a substantial biomedical engineering project.
The graduate attributes are assessed primarily through reports and presentations.
Work within a team to advance a design project
Investigate a need in biomedical engineering (this includes determining investigation approaches that are feasible and effective given the timeframe and the particular need and context)
Develop and screen design concepts that are consistent with requirements and constraints
Develop well justified engineering specifications for a design concept
Analyze and iterate a design concept through analysis, modelling, and/or prototyping
Recognize and document safety, ethical, and regulatory considerations relevant to a design concept
Identify and address gaps in their competence to carry out a design project

General Terms of Assessment:
Your competence in execution of the engineering design process and in application of engineering knowledge, skills and tools.
Your ability to communicate in writing and orally at an appropriate level
Your attention to ethics, safety and risk management in terms of both your project work and the larger scale ethics and safety of your design
Your ability to make good decisions and apply sound engineering judgement
All design projects are expected to be substantial and to demonstrate a suitable level of technical expertise and engineering competence for 4th year biomedical engineering students.
To assist with completion of a sufficiently substantive and complex project, projects should be completed in teams of 4-5 students.
For the purpose of BME capstone projects, "biomedical engineering" is defined as follows (adapted from Enderle & Bronzino, Introduction to Biomedical Engineering):

This field combines the design and problem solving skills of engineering with medical and biological sciences to advance health and health care treatment, including diagnosis, monitoring, and therapy.

Students should be able to present an appropriate budget and plan for the project, discuss safety, health, ethical and equity issues around their solution, as well as identify potential economic, societal and environmental impacts that may need mitigation through design.

topics: Notice of Recording
Fundamentals in Neural and Rehabilitation Engineering Fall 2024
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
DWE 2402
Introduction to the field of neural and rehabilitation engineering (NRE).

Topics include describing common neurological and musculoskeletal injuries, related neural and rehabilitation engineering approaches to address disabilities, and the development of a design framework for synthesizing a novel neural and rehabilitation engineering approach.
Critical concepts in clinical research design to meet current regulatory, ethical, and practice policies will be studied.
Describe and apply evidence-based medicine (EBM) concepts applied to NRE.
Evaluate and criticize existing neural and rehabilitation engineering (NRE) approaches.
Synthesize and disseminate a novel innovation to solve a self-selected problem in NRE.
There are 12 graduate attributes total and collection of these attributes is pertinent in ensuring our engineering programs remain accredited.
This is an upper year elective course introducing the field of neural and rehabilitation engineering (NRE) by exposing students to the key problems and current engineering approaches.
The first half of the course will focus on describing common neurological and musculoskeletal injuries and related NRE approaches to address disabilities.
Subsequent classes will examine critical concepts in clinical research design to meet current regulatory, ethical, and practice policies.
At the end of the term, students will pitch their proposal to a panel of judges, representing clinical and industry stakeholders.

Hands-on labs will teach students the integration of mechanical, electrical, and software systems through building a soft robotic finger prosthesis along with inertial measurement units, electromyography and electroencephalography.

major_name: Biomedical Engineering (Bachelor of Applied Science - Honours)
topics: Biomechanics of Human Movement Fall 2024
This course introduces students to the biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system, including motor control and rehabilitation engineering.
Motor control will be included, as well as the identification of body segment parameters and the dynamics of muscles.
Biomechanics applies techniques of engineering mechanics to the study of biological organisms.
This course is specifically concerned with “musculoskeletal biomechanics”, the application of engineering mechanics to the study of the human musculoskeletal system.
We will further limit our interest to the use of kinematics and rigid-body dynamics to model the human body and its movement.

During this process, you will become well versed in the patterns of human motion, inverse and forward dynamic analyses of human motion, robotics, model development and validation, and interpretation of model predictions.
Assumed knowledge: The course assumes knowledge of basic concepts in statics, linear algebra, differential equations, and elementary dynamics.
1) Extend a singular rigid body system to develop a lumped-mass multibody model.
3) Develop equations to solve these representative models and simulate the human body motions or those of a robot.
4) Validate the developed human body models using motion capture technology to simulate a multifaceted human movement.
6a) Use human body models to distinguish normal and pathological motion and force patterns.
